decision_conditions: The Ash is located at the bottom of St Gregory Close, alongside the fence that separates the properties in St Gregory Close from the adjacent properties in The Croft. The Ash is a large specimen visible from the residents of St Gregory Close and residents of the adjacent dwellings at The Croft. The tree has a moderate-to-high amenity value and significantly contributes to the arboreal character of the area, which is partially deprived in mature tree cover.

The applicant has chosen in the application form the option stating the tree is diseased or might break or fall; by ticking this option the applicant is required to provide written arboricultural advice from an appropriate expert. The applicant has provided a quotation from a landscaping company (ArborMaster UK Ltd) for the removal of the tree, but has provided no arboricultural assessment from a qualified arboriculturalist. The applicant has also declared alleged damage to the property, for which a report from an engineer or survey
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981:  Note that it is an offence under this act to disturb roosting bats, nesting birds or any other protected species.  Therefore, if applicable, it is advisable to consult your tree surgeon / consultant to agree an acceptable time for carrying out the approved works.
application_type_full: Tree works: Trees in conservation areas/subject to TPOs
description: To fell one ash, T1 on TPO 350
